Heather, thanks for point to this paper.  I know we've talked about it of=
f the list, but I wanted to mention on the list that I think that it makes =
a lot of sense to sometimes use novelty search to collect a diversity of be=
haviors (for various possible reasons) rather than to try to find a best on=
e.  This paper is a great example that such an interesting-behavior-collect=
ing application can work and it may turn out that this type of application =
ultimately becomes more common than the "best-solution" variety.

ken

--- =
In neat@yahoogroups.com, Heather Goldsby <hjg@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Everyone:
=
> 
> I'm pleased to announce a new novelty search paper that will be
> appe=
aring in the proceedings of the ACM/IEEE International Conference
> on Mode=
l Driven Engineering Languages and Systems (MoDELS 2010), a
> software engi=
neering conference.
> 
> Heather J. Goldsby and Betty H.C. Cheng (2010)
> A=
utomatically Discovering Properties that Specify the Latent Behavior
> of U=
ML Models
> http://www.cse.msu.edu/~hjg/Publications_files/goldsby2010Novel=
ty.pdf
> 
> This paper describes how we used novelty search to discover a s=
et of
> properties that describe the behavior of software models, where som=
e
> properties likely represent bugs. One difference from previous novelty
=
> search papers is that our end objective is to collect a suite of  
> solu=
tions,
> rather than looking for one ideal solution.
> 
> I'm very interest=
ed in hearing what the novelty search community
> thinks of these results.
=
> 
> Thanks!
> 
> Heather Goldsby
> 
> Digital Evolution Laboratory
> Michi=
gan State University
> www.cse.msu.edu/~hjg
>
